reviews.review_text: I 'finished' the main story of this game (with help from GameFAQs and some Youtube.  I'll admit, I feel 'stupid' playing the Lego games as I quite often don't 'get' what I'm supposed to do to complete each area, and I wish the saves were at any time and not so rare, as sometimes I've lost progress because I needed to quit for the day and couldn't save some progress.  Still, the game is fun, its enjoyable, and worth buying.  I hope there's a sequel, and it seems to hint so at the end of the game. I won't spoil the ending, but its worth watching.  The voices are great. The levels fun. Its a keeper.

As far as LEGO games go, this game is definitely... well, a LEGO game.  What I mean by this is that if you have ever played a LEGO game in your life then you already know everything there is to know mechanically about this game. In my experience, LEGO games are not so much about ground breaking, innovative gameplay; but rather, immensely enjoyable fun for the whole family that comes in all kinds of assorted flavors. Personally, I find the Star Wars flavor to be the best out of all of them, but for the same reason that a die-hard LOTR fan would tell you that the Lord of the Rings LEGO Games are the best.  Overall, if you haven't ever played a LEGO game, then don't just buy the 'latest and greatest'. Buy a flavor you love, and I promise you won't be disappointed :)

Grand Theft Auto Gotham, with Legos. It's a surprisingly good blend of Adam West Batman with Tim Burton Batman. Lots to unlock and a good-sized area to explore outside of the regular main quests. Amusing cutscenes, good puzzles, incentive to explore...I'm enjoying it. Downsides: Camera is not your friend sometimes, and you'll want to use a gamepad (which was awkward to get working to replace the keyboard-only default controls). Also no online play, which is a shame - just two people on the same computer.

There needs to be a third option for 'do you recommend this game?'  Lego Batman 2 introduces a lot of nice new features, like a giant city hubworld to explore that feels a lot like the city from Arkham City, as well as opening up the character roster beyond the batman universe, and many of these characters feel different to play as.  But Lego Batman 2 is still a lego game. A puzzler brawler hybrid that's about a step above a facebook game... and for me that loses it's apeal fast. It's still got some entertainment value... the original story and voice acting actually serve the game quite nicely. But if you've played other lego games and found yourself getting bored, look for this on sale or skip it entirely. After a 10 hour story and 2 hours of just messing around, you may not find yourself anxious to return again.

This is the 2nd Lego game I've played, the first being Marvel Super Heroes, and I found this game to be quite enjoyable. I enjoyed this a bit more than the Marvel game but I think a lot of that is because I knew what to expect from it and didn't have as much trouble navigating and using the map to find collectibles. The story portion of the game is short but is pretty fun and light hearted, yet fits in well with the DC and more specifically Batman universe. There are a good number of heroes and villains that you can unlock and play as from both the Batman, Superman and Justice League comics for those familiar with the 2 comics. The only downside to this is that there is not a whole lot reason to use more than a handful of core characters that have abilities that you will find useful quite often. But on the other hand, some characters are basically clones of others in terms of their abilities so you can take your pick of who you'd rather play as.  If you want to just play the story mode, you could probably beat it in 10 hours or less. However there is so much more to do between collectibles and replaying levels in Free Play mode to try and find things that you weren't able to when you played in story mode. Also this is a fun game if you have a kid and want to play local 2 player co-op. I've played this some with my nephew who is 5 and while he's still learning, he can actually do pretty well. I would probably say that it's best suited for kids 7+ but still fun to have something that the 2 of you can play. Overall there is a lot to do and if you plan to get 100% as I did, then be prepared to put in some hours. This seems to be a staple of the Lego games based on the 2 I've played. However, my time played as recorded by Steam is a bit exaggerated due to times when I left the game on pause for long periods of time and times that I played with my nephew on a separate file. However, if you want to go for it all, I'd expect 25-30 hours. The only bad thing about the game is that you can only save your progress at checkpoints during levels and usually when you get collectibles it auto-saves. That's why I had to leave the game on pause for long periods of time a few times because I really had to be somewhere and just didn't have time to get to the next collectible or checkpoint. So just keep that in mind when deciding whether or not to continue playing a level, go for particular collectibles, etc.  Overall, I would definitely recommend this game as something fun for all ages of gamers.
